projectDesc.p: "A witty reply from the same poet" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Huic ipsi inter seniorem aliquando iunioremque Canes prandenti, cum ministri utriusque, dedita opera, ante pedes Dantis, ad eum lacessendum, ossa occulte subiecissent,
app.rdg:
Dante was once seated for dinner between the older and younger Cangrande
Literally "big dog", when their servants intentionally tried to hurt him by secretly throwing bones in front of his feet.

app.lem: remota mensa, versi omnes in solum Dantem, mirabantur, cur ante ipsum solummodo ossa conspicerentur.
app.rdg: When the table was removed everyone turned toward Dante and wondered why there were bones in front of him only.

app.lem: Tum ille, ut erat ad respondendum promptus:
app.rdg: To which Dante, always prepared to reply, said:

app.lem: 'Minime,' inquit, 'mirum, si Canes ossa sua comederunt: ego autem non sum Canis.'
app.rdg: “It is little wonder if the dogs have eaten their bones, but I am not a dog!”
